STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 31, 2024
JILL SCHREUDER
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - MUSKEGON
1720 PARK ST,
MUSKEGON, MI, 49441-2403
Re: License #: CB610201023
Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
July 25, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB610201023
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL CHRISTINE SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: JILL CHRISTINE SCHREUDER
Name of Agency: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
MUSKEGON
Agency Address: 1720 PARK ST
MUSKEGON, MI 49441-2403
Agency Telephone #: 2317264735
Original Issuance Date: 02/01/1991
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation
from the medical or dental provider of all medical
and dental care received by a foster child.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have all medical and dental appointments
documented in the case file.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the Initial Service Plan completed
timely as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
2

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan
completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
• (3) The record must contain all the following
information:
• (g) A photograph taken at least annually.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the youth picture updated annually
as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
3

Permanent Ward Service Pla – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, stepdown
from a residential or hospital setting, return from
AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.
Four of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Five of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have
been found to produce positive outcome for children in
4

foster care. A quality visit is defined as one in which the
caseworker:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss
the current placement.
• View the child’s bedroom and sleeping
arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for
infants under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s education, medical, dental,
mental health and other needs and takes
appropriate action or offers services in response
to the identified needs of each child.
• Shows interest in the child to build and establish
rapport.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the
plan for parenting time, visits with siblings and
other relatives, and the child’s permanency plan,
in a developmentally appropriate way while
allowing the child to ask question and express
viewpoints.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
One file did not document the worker met with each child individually, viewed
bedroom and sleeping arrangements, assessed current needs of the child(ren) or
shared/explained the case plan. The second file did not document the worker met
with the child individually, viewed bedroom and sleeping arrangement or
shared/explained the case plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days of the end of the report period.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
5

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Six of six foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the parent agency treatment plan (PATP) or the signatures were not obtained
timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parent if the child is temporary
court ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
6

• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment or services prior to or at the first
schedule appointment while the foster care case
is open, regardless of placement. Subsequent
medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults
aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
Six of six foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
6/29/2022 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/28/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Documenting SOGIE and special characteristics foster parents are willing to
take needs to be thorough.
• Be sure to consider agency policies/procedures when deciding special
investigation findings.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or corporal
punishment during this licensing period.
7

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency renewal inspection was completed on 7/6/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 7/26/2023. The agency was cited for 13 violations, 6 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 6, 2 of the violations stayed the same (FTM's and
timely service plans. There was a slight decrease in 1 area (1105's) and there was
an increase in the number of individual incidents in the other 3 areas (medical
passports, quality visits and PATP's).
The agency interim inspection was completed on 6/29/2022 and the CAP was
approved on 7/28/2022. The agency was cited for 10 violations, 7 of which were
repeated this year. 5 of the 7 violations (medical passports, FTM's, 1105's, PATP's
and quality visits) have increased in the number of individual incidents of non-
compliance this year while the remaining 2 (supervisory approval and timely
service plans) are the same. The agency will need to establish additional
corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The Chief Administrator
indicated the agency has experienced staff turnover over the past review period.
The time between hiring new staff and the training period may cause some areas
where requirements are missed. As a result of the previous year's audit the
agency developed a CAP that they feel has been beneficial in some areas. As a
result of the CAP the agency increased training, tracking and close supervisory
monitoring. In addition, the agency emphasized weekly review of the Book of
Business as a monitoring tool. The agency also implemented staff conducted
audits where staff audit two of their own cases and two peer audits. This has
helped to ensure documents are properly uploaded and contacts are completed
timely.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency as well as coworkers. Staff did not report any concerns
that are specific to the agency but some frustration with some of the systemic
requirements.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely including CHRI.
8

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
______7/25/2024_____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
7/31/2024
________________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
